net.sourceforge.JDash.ecu.comm
Interface ECUMonitor

All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Runnable
All Known Implementing Classes:
BaseMonitor, ELMScanMonitor, KWP2000Monitor, LoggerPlaybackMonitor, NissanConsultMonitor, RS232Monitor, SSMOBD1Monitor, SSMOBD2Monitor, TestMonitor
public interface ECUMonitor
extends java.lang.Runnable

An ECU Monitor represents the methos required by the main applicaiton to communicate with the ECU. The steps the app will follow on the concrete monitor are 1. init() 2. addAllParam() 3. start the monitor in it's own thread.

Method Detail

init

java.util.List<Parameter> init(ParameterRegistry reg,
                               InitListener initListener)
                               throws java.lang.Exception
This method will get called to initialize the monitor. The return list is a list of parameters that this monitor claims to support. It is not actually the list of parameters used. Infact, the return list is at present, optional. Ror example, the SSM monitor will return the available sensors for the ECU it's connected to. And OBD-II monitor might do the same. The main DashboardFrame is passed into the monitor on init, giving the monitor a chance to do some GUI work before starting. The reason for passing the frame is go provide an owner frame to center dialog boxes around. You should not really directly affect the frame itself.

Returns:
a list of parameters that this monitor claims to support. This is a list for reference only, it is NOT used to initialize anything.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - if there is a fatal init problem.

getEcuInfo

java.lang.String getEcuInfo()
                            throws java.lang.Exception
Returns:
a string with monitor specific ecu info. Can contain info such as the ECU ID, verions code, date, comm type, etc etc.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

addParam

void addParam(Parameter param)
This method will be called to add a single parameter to this monitor for monitoring.

getParams

java.util.List<ECUParameter> getParams()
Get the list of parameters this moniotor is tracking.

Returns:
the list of parametres.

resetDTCs

void resetDTCs()
               throws java.lang.Exception
Since DTCs are usualy a bit different, and this is a rare to-ecu command, we define this here. This forces any monitor to include the ability to reset the DTCs. But.. it is NOT necessary for the monitor to actually do it. If the monitor can't reset DTCs, then throw an exception. The GaugePanel will display the message to the user.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception

stop

void stop()
Tell this monitor to stop it's monitoring, and close it's connection. Note that this does NOT mean that the thread is stopped right away. This will flip a flag indicating to the thread that it should finish what it's currently doing, and then exit normally. It is the job of the thread owner to watch for the thread to finish before moving on.
